 You're confusing terms - Mayr isn't talking about phyletic gradualism there. Phyletic gradualism is the idea that evolution happens at a steady rate, as opposed to punctuated equilibria, which states that periods of relative stability are punctuated by relatively rapid change. However, even with punctuated equilibria, evolution is "gradual" in the sense that it takes a stepwise progression (as opposed to saltationism) - and that's the sense that Mayr and Dawkins use it.

 [...]
 The fact is that, in the fullest and most serious sense, Eldredge and Gould are really just as gradualist as Darwin or any of his followers.
